# Public Prosecutor _v_ Pay Wee Meng  

### \[2022\] SGMC 24

<table id="info-table"><tbody><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Case Number</td><td class="txt-body">Magistrate's Court Notice No. 901710 of 2021 and 3 Others, Magistrate's Appeal No. 9066-2022-01</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Decision Date</td><td class="txt-body">05 May 2022</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Tribunal/Court</td><td class="txt-body">Magistrates Court</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Coram</td><td class="txt-body">Karolyn Gin</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Counsel Name(s)</td><td class="txt-body">DPP Ng Shao Yan (Attorney-General's Chambers) for the Public Prosecutor; Accused-in-person.</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Parties</td><td class="txt-body">Public Prosecutor — Pay Wee Meng</td></tr></tbody></table>

Criminal Procedure and Sentencing – Sentencing – Principles

Criminal Law – Statutory offences – Protection from Harassment Act

\[LawNet Editorial Note: An appeal to this decision has been filed in MA 9066/2022/01.\]

5 May 2022

### District Judge Karolyn Gin:

1       The Accused, Mr Pay Wee Meng (26 years old), had pleaded guilty to the following charges of unlawful stalking under section 7(1) of the Protection from Harassment Act (Cap 256A, 2015 Rev. Ed.) (“the Act”):

> MCN-901710-2021 (1st Charge)

> You,… are charged that you, from 2016 to 2018, in Singapore, did unlawfully stalk one (C) (“the Victim”) by engaging in a course of conduct which involved acts associated with stalking, _to wit_, you:

>> i.    Created posts on the social media platform, SgGirls.com (“the Platform”), containing photographs of the Victim;

>> ii.    Pretended to be the Victim on the Platform; and

>> iii.   Made communications to other persons on the Platform purporting to originate from the Victim and suggesting that the Victim was open to having sex with strangers,

> thereby causing distress to the Victim, when you ought reasonably to have known that your conduct was likely to cause distress to the Victim, and you have thereby contravened Section 7(1) of the Protection from Harassment Act (Chapter 256A, 2015 Rev Ed) and committed an offence punishable under Section 7(6) of the same Act.

> MCN-901711-2021 (2nd Charge)

> You,… are charged that you, from 2016 to 2021, in Singapore, did unlawfully stalk one (C) (“the Victim”) by engaging in a course of conduct which involved acts associated with stalking, _to wit_, you:

>> i.    Created posts on the social media platform, Tumblr (“the Platform”), containing photographs of the Victim;

>> ii.    Pretended to be the Victim on the Platform; and

>> iii.   Made communications to other persons on the Platform purporting to originate from the Victim and suggesting that the Victim was open to having sex with strangers,

> thereby causing distress to the Victim, when you ought reasonably to have known that your conduct was likely to cause distress to the Victim, and you have thereby contravened Section 7(1) of the Protection from Harassment Act (Chapter 256A, 2015 Rev Ed) and committed an offence punishable under Section 7(6) of the same Act.

2       Two other charges under section 7 of the Act were taken into consideration.

3       After having considered the Prosecution’s submissions on sentence and the Accused’s mitigation plea, I sentenced the Accused to an imprisonment term of 12 weeks’ imprisonment on each charge. Both sentences were ordered to run concurrently.

4       The Accused’s request for a deferment of two weeks was granted. Subsequently, by way of APP-2022-0324-65966, the Accused applied for further deferment and a deferment of three weeks was granted.

5       Thereafter, the Accused filed application APP-2022-0328-67428 requesting further mention. Due to information from his company that he could not apply for three months’ leave, he sought a lower sentence such as six weeks’ imprisonment or a fine.

6       As the sentence had already been imposed, the application for further mention was not granted.

7       The Accused then filed an appeal and these are the grounds for my decision.

## Statement of Facts

8       A summary of the facts as contained in the Statement of Facts (“SOF”), which the Accused has admitted to without qualification, are set out as follows.

9       The Accused was the Victim’s schoolmate in secondary school and she was 19 years old at the earliest time of the offences.

10     After the Accused graduated from secondary school, he started creating accounts on various social media platforms using the Victim’s name and photographs. He obtained these photographs from the Victim’s social media account. Using the accounts which he created, he posted captions with sexual connotations as he wanted other guys to talk to him about sex.

11     From 2016 to 2018 and from 2016 to 2021, in Singapore, the Accused did unlawfully stalk the Victim by using the social media platforms, SgGirls.com and Tumblr respectively (collectively “the Platforms”). He did this by engaging in a course of conduct which involved acts associated with stalking as follows:

> i.     Creating posts on the Platforms, containing photographs of the victim;

> ii.     Pretending to be the Victim of the Platforms; and

> iii.     Making communications to other persons on the Platforms purporting to originate from the Victim and suggesting that the Victim was open to having sex with strangers.

12     As a result of the Accused’s conduct, the Victim was informed by her friends and strangers on multiple occasions that there was someone impersonating her on the Platforms and stating that she was open to having sex with strangers. Upon checking, the Victim found her photographs circulating on various social media platforms with accompanying posts soliciting for sex. She was also contacted by strangers who requested to meet up with her for sex. Even the Victim’s friends received texts from strangers asking them if they knew the Victim.

13     This caused distress to the Victim. The Accused ought reasonably to have known that his conduct was likely to cause distress to the Victim.

14     The Accused had thereby contravened section 7(1) of the Protection from Harassment Act (Chapter 256A, 2015 Rev Ed) and committed two counts of an offence punishable under section 7(6) of the same Act.

15     The Accused had also engaged in the aforementioned acts associated with stalking against the Victim on ASK.FM from 2017 to 2018 and Instagram in 2017 (subject of the charges taken into consideration).

## Prescribed Penalties

16     The prescribed punishment for an offence under section 7(1) of the Act is a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or both.

## Antecedents

17     The Accused was untraced.

## Prosecution’s Submissions on Sentence

18     The Prosecution referred to the sentencing framework as set out in the three-Judge High Court decision of _Lee Shing Chan v Public Prosecutor and another appeal_ <span class="citation">\[2020\] SGHC 41</span> (“_Lee Shing Chan_”) and submitted the present offence should be classified as low harm and medium culpability under that framework, albeit at the higher end of the range. This was derived as follows.

19      Low harm:

The Accused caused harm to the Victim’s reputation and mental health through his conduct. He suggested that the Victim was open to having sex with strangers by posting her photographs on the accounts which he created, impersonating the Victim and making sexual posts with these accounts. The Victim was contacted by strangers asking her for sex and the harm extended to third parties because the Victim’s friends were also contacted by strangers to try and get to the Victim through them.

20     In the similar case of _Public Prosecutor v Lim Teck Guan_ <span class="citation">\[2021\] SGMC 2</span> (“_Lim Teck Guan_”), the court found that the case fell within the medium harm category in the Framework. In _Lim Teck Guan_, the accused posted compromising photographs of the victim, including photographs of her topless in bed, with captions containing sexual innuendos. The accused publicly identified the victim through her occupation and place of work. He also extended the harm to third parties by posting the contact list of the victim’s colleagues and associates. He further caused distress to the victim by threatening her.

21     The Prosecution submitted that the harm caused to the Victim in the present case was lower than in _Lim Teck Guan_ and would fall under low harm. The photographs the Accused posted on the platforms were not as egregious as in _Lim Teck Guan_. He also did not go as far as to identify where the Victim worked, the contacts of her friends and colleagues or cause her further distress by threatening her. Accordingly, the present case should be classified as low harm.

22      Medium culpability:

The Accused’s offending conduct lasted for a long time, from 2016 to 2018 on SgGirls.com and 2016 to 2021 on Tumblr. His motive for the offences arose out of self-interest. In order to get others to speak to him about sex, he chose to impersonate the Victim at the cost of her reputation. He disseminated photographs of the Victim on platforms without her consent and solicited for sex while purporting to be her. The Accused did this on multiple platforms (including those cited in the charges taken into consideration) thereby causing the Victim’s photographs to be disseminated more extensively.

23     In _Lim Teck Guan_, the court found that the case fell within the category of medium culpability. There, the accused intended to cause distress to the victim and he committed the offence out of self-interest to re-open communication channels with the victim. There was also an abuse of trust as the accused was only able to obtain the compromising photographs of the victim through his previous intimate relationship with the accused.

24     The Prosecution submitted that the culpability in the present case would be similar to that in _Lim Teck Guan_. Whilst the mental element in the present case was less serious than in _Lim Teck Guan_, the offences were committed over a longer period of time and on several platforms.

25     The Prosecution submitted that a starting point sentence of 16 weeks’ imprisonment would be appropriate in the present case as the Accused would fall under the higher end of the range in the category of low harm and moderate culpability. From there, a downwards calibration of the sentence to 12 weeks’ imprisonment would be appropriate after taking into account the Accused’s plea of guilt.

## Mitigation Plea

26     The Accused was in person. In his mitigation plea, the Accused sought a fine or if there was a jail sentence, a deferment of sentence of two weeks in order to explain to his manager about the sentence. He pleaded for a light sentence, saying he did not earn much and needed to support his family.

## My Decision

### The Applicable Law

27     In _Lee Shing Chan_ at \[35\], the court set out the following sentencing framework for unlawful stalking cases under s7 of the Act.

> (a)     Identify the level of harm caused by the offence (slight, moderate or severe) and level of culpability (low, medium or high), having regard to the offence-specific factors.

> (b)     Identify the applicable indicative sentencing range by reference to the following matrix.

![](data:image;base64,)

> (c)     Identify the appropriate starting point within that range, having regard again to the offence-specific factors.

> (d)     Adjust the starting point based on offender-specific aggravating and mitigating factors.

> (e)     Where an offender has been convicted of multiple charges, consider whether further adjustments are necessary to take into account the totality principle.

28     The non-exhaustive list of offence-specific factors are tabulated below:

<table align="left" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="Judg-2-tblr" frame="all" pgwide="0"><colgroup><col width="50%"><col width="50%"></colgroup><tbody><tr><td align="left" class="b" colspan="2" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="center" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Offence-specific factors</b></p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="center" class="Table-Para-1"><u>Factors going towards harm</u></p></td><td align="left" class="" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="center" class="Table-Para-1"><u>Factors going towards culpability</u></p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(a) Type and extent of harm to the victim (including harm to safety, health, reputation, economic position or freedom to do any act he or she is legally entitled to do or not to do any act he or she is not legally bound to do)</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(b) Type and extent of harm to third parties</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(c) The victim’s age, physical and mental health and personality</p></td><td align="left" class="" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(a) Offender’s <em>mens rea</em> (whether the offender intended to cause harassment, alarm or distress, knew his or her conduct was likely to so cause, or ought reasonably to have known this)</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(b) Offender’s motive</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(c) Offender’s age, difference in age between victim and offender</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(d) Whether the offender is of low IQ or suffering from a mental condition, which causally affected the commission of the offence and substantially affected the offender’s mental responsibility</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(e) Degree of premeditation, planning or sophistication</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(f) Particular combination or nature of acts that make up the course of conduct (<em>eg</em>, public dissemination of sensitive information, the making of threats, exceptional duration or frequency of stalking)</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(g) Targeting of vulnerable victim (but not a situation covered by s&nbsp;8A of the POHA)</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(h) Victim belonging to a class that warrants special protection, including public servants or public service workers (but not a situation covered by s 8A of the POHA)</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(i) Abuse of position, breach of trust (but not a situation covered by s&nbsp;8B of the POHA)</p></td></tr></tbody></table>

  
  

29     The non-exhaustive list of offender-specific factors are tabulated below:

<table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="Judg-2-tblr" frame="all" pgwide="0"><colgroup><col width="50%"><col width="50%"></colgroup><tbody><tr><td align="left" class="b" colspan="2" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="center" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Offender-specific factors</b></p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="center" class="Table-Para-1"><u>Aggravating factors</u></p></td><td align="left" class="" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="center" class="Table-Para-1"><u>Mitigating factors</u></p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(a) Offences taken into consideration for sentencing purposes</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(b) Relevant antecedents</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(c)Evident lack of remorse</p></td><td align="left" class="" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(a) Guilty plea</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(b) Cooperation with the authorities</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">(c) Voluntary apology or actions taken to minimise further harm to victim</p></td></tr></tbody></table>

  
  

30     I have applied the above framework to the facts of the present case as follows.

### Harm Caused

31     As mentioned above, the Prosecution submitted that the present case would be suitably classified as one of low harm.

32     The Accused caused harm to the Victim’s reputation and mental health by suggesting that the Victim was open to having sex with strangers by posting her photographs on the accounts which he created, impersonating the Victim and making sexual posts with these accounts. The Victim’s stress was aggravated by how she was contacted by strangers asking her for sex . Further, the harm extended to third parties because the Victim’s friends were also contacted by strangers who tried to get to the Victim through them.

33     The Victim was 19 years old at the earliest time of the offences.

34     In _Lim Teck Guan_, the court found that the case fell within the medium harm category in the framework. The present case is similar to _Lim Teck Guan_ in that the Accused posted photos of the Victim with sexual innuendos. However, the photographs the Accused posted on the platforms were not as egregious as in _Lim Teck Guan_ and the Accused did not go as far as to identify where the Victim worked, the contacts of her friends and colleagues or cause her further distress by threatening her.

35     Accordingly, I agree with the view of the Prosecution that the present case should be classified as low harm, albeit at the higher end of that range.

### Culpability

36     The Accused’s offending conduct lasted for a long time, from 2016 to 2018 on SgGirls.com and 2016 to 2021 on Tumblr. Motivated out of self-interest, he impersonated the Victim at the cost of her reputation. He disseminated photographs of the Victim on platforms extensively on multiple platforms (including those in the charges taken into consideration) without her consent and solicited for sex while purporting to be her.

37     In _Lim Teck Guan_, the court found that the case fell within the category of medium culpability. There, the accused intended to cause distress to the victim and committed the offence out of self-interest to re-open communication channels with the victim. There was also an abuse of trust as the accused was only able to obtain the compromising photographs of the victim through his previous intimate relationship with the accused.

38     Here, although the mental element in the present case was less serious than in _Lim Teck Guan_, the offences were committed over a longer period of time and on several platforms.

39     In light of the above, I agree with the Prosecution that the present case should be classified as moderate harm under the sentencing framework in _Lee Shing Chan_.

40     Since I classified the present case as low harm and medium culpability, under the framework in _Lee Shing Chan_, the custodial threshold was crossed. I also agree with the Prosecution that a starting point sentence of 16 weeks’ imprisonment would be appropriate in the present case as the Accused would fall under the higher end of the range in the category of low harm and moderate culpability.

41     The Accused sought a fine or if there was a jail sentence, a deferment of sentence of two weeks in order to explain to his manager about the sentence. He pleaded for a light sentence, saying he did not earn much and needed to support his family.

42     In _Public Prosecutor v Gaiyathiri d/o Murugayan_ <span class="citation">\[2021\] SGHC 187</span>, the High Court stated:

> It is well-established in law that personal or family hardship are not mitigating factors unless there are clearly exceptional reasons for taking them into account (see _Lai Oei Mui Jenny v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[1993\] 2 SLR(R) 406</span> at \[11\]-\[12\]; _Lim Choon Kang v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[1993\] 3 SLR(R) 254</span> at \[5\]; _Leaw Siat Chong v Public Prosecutor_ <span class="citation">\[2001\] 3 SLR(R) 646</span> at \[12\]; _Public Prosecutor v Loqmanul Hakim bin Buang_ <span class="citation">\[2007\] 4 SLR(R) 753</span> at \[73\]).

43     In _Public Prosecutor v Loqmanul Hakim bin Buang_ <span class="citation">\[2007\] 4 SLR(R) 753</span>, the High Court highlighted that “…such hardship to the family would be the inevitable price that must be paid for the moment of folly and cannot affect what would otherwise be an appropriate sentence.”

44     In the present case, there were no exceptional reasons given for taking into account personal or family hardship.

45     After taking into account the Accused’s plea of guilt, an appropriate sentence would be 12 weeks’ imprisonment for each charge.

## Conclusion

46     Accordingly, after hearing the sentencing submissions of the Prosecution and mitigation plea of the Accused, I sentenced the Accused to 12 weeks’ imprisonment for each charge. Both sentences were ordered to run concurrently.
